titlestmt.titleproper: Jodie Hearon Photograph Collection, 1953-1972, undated SC 26
titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to his Photographs at the Indiana University Archives of African American Music and Culture
titlestmt.author: AAAMC staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of African American Music and Culture

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-02-18 21:07:26 -0500.

repository.corpname: Archives of African American Music and Culture

did.unittitle: Jodie Hearon Photograph Collection
did.abstract: Thirty-nine photographs depicting rural life in Mississippi circa 1953-1964.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jodie Hearon lived and worked in farming and agriculture in Mississippi during a period of industrializationa and mechanization. Hearon and his wife, Ella, managed farming, dairy, and livestock operations. The Hearons chose to attempt a capital intensive strategy of purchasing industrial and mechanized farming equipment, while also employing local families as sharecroppers and wage-workers, to work much of the land that was previously owned by plantation-owner Palmer H. Brooks in the area of Drew, Mississippi. Photographs from the collection indicate that some or all of the family relocated to St. Louis, Missouri by the late 1960s. An interview with Jodie and Ella Hearon was conducted in Memphis, Tennessee on July 3, 1989 [see related material].

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Use of time-based media materials (audio and video) may require production of listening or viewing copies.

Access to streaming audio, moving image, and full resolution digital image materials may currently be restricted to researchers who can authenticate with an IU account or who are physically present on campus. Remote streaming to individual researchers may be allowed with the completion of applicable forms.
For further information about access to online audiovisual materials, contact AAAMC staff at aaamc@indiana.edu.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Manuscript collections and archival records may contain materials with sensitive or confidential information that is protected under federal or state right to privacy laws and regulations, including but not limited to the Indiana Public Records Act (5-14-3-2 et seq.). Researchers are advised that the disclosure of certain information pertaining to identifiable living individuals represented in this collection without the consent of those individuals may have legal ramifications (e.g., a cause of action under common law for invasion of privacy may arise if facts concerning an individual's private life are published that would be deemed highly offensive to a reasonable person) for which Indiana University assumes no responsibility.

Copyright is retained by the creators/authors of items in this collection, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law. All requests for copying and publishing materials must be submitted in writing to the Archives of African American Music and Culture, and may require the written permission of the creator(s)/author(s) or donor(s).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jodie Hearon Photograph Collection, SC 26, Archives of African American Music and Culture, Indiana University, Bloomington.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by AAAMC Staff. Completed in 2019.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See related article, "The Impact of Mechanized Farming on Black Farm Families in the Rural South: A Study of Farm Life in the Brooks Farm Community, 1940-1970," by Valerie Grimm in Agricultural History, Vol. 68, No. 2, Eli Whitney's Cotton Gin, 1793-1993: A Symposium (Spring 1994), pp. 169-1970. Contact the AAAMC for access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of photographs depicting rural life in Mississippi circa 1953-1964. Most of the photographs were taken at Brooks Farm or Greenwood Farm in Drew, Mississippi. Descriptions were provided by Jodie Hearon.

did.unittitle: 1. Photographs
Jodie Hearon, Alex Ingram, Sonny Hill, Ms. Ella posed with mule-drawn wagons, GMC truck & 1952 Oldsmobile
did.abstract: They are driving four mules with a roll of corn, with one line, and Alex is driving a pair of mules that are hauling corn. Sonny is driving the GMC truck with a load of corn they are taking to the barn for the animals. The farm is on Humphrey highway in Greenwood.

dao.xlink:title: Jodie Hearon, Alex Ingram, Sonny Hill, Ms. Ella posed with mule-drawn wagons, GMC truck & 1952 Oldsmobile, 1953

daodesc.p: Jodie Hearon, Alex Ingram, Sonny Hill, Ms. Ella posed with mule-drawn wagons, GMC truck & 1952 Oldsmobile, 1953

did.unittitle: Jodie Hearon's farmhouse and cotton field in Drew, Mississippi
did.abstract: The house had two bathrooms, four bedrooms, living room, dining room, and a kitchen. It was modern for that time- there were not a lot of houses on Brooks Farm with running water and bathrooms.

dao.xlink:title: Jodie Hearon's farmhouse and cotton field in Drew, Mississippi, 1964

daodesc.p: Jodie Hearon's farmhouse and cotton field in Drew, Mississippi, 1964

did.unittitle: Seven trailers hauling bails of cotton, and cotton picker [machine] in field at Brooks Farm
did.abstract: Mechanization had come to the farm by 1964.

daodesc.p: Seven trailers hauling bails of cotton, and cotton picker [machine] in field at Brooks Farm, 1964
